title: Trump nominates Kevin Warsh as Federal Reserve Chair
content: President Donald Trump has nominated former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh to succeed Jerome Powell, whose term expires in May. The announcement on 30 January triggered a sharp reversal in precious metals and a stabilisation in the US dollar as markets weighed Warsh's reputation for 'sound money' hawkishness.
summary: Donald Trump selects Kevin Warsh to lead the Federal Reserve, sparking immediate volatility in gold and currency markets.
context:
• The nomination follows months of public tension between the White House and current Chair Jerome Powell over interest rate policy.

• Kevin Warsh is widely viewed as a candidate who may favour shrinking the Fed's balance sheet more aggressively than his predecessor.

• The transition comes at a critical juncture as the US economy grapples with a policy pause after a series of late-2025 rate cuts.
happened:
• Gold prices plunged over 8% to below $4,900 per ounce on 30 January, retreating from a record high of $5,586 set just 24 hours earlier.

• The US Dollar Index ($DXY) climbed slightly from four-year lows, while 10-year Treasury yields rose by 2 basis points to 4.24%.

• Silver experienced extreme volatility, sinking to roughly $82 per ounce after peaking at $121 earlier in the week.
implications:
• A Warsh-led Fed may prioritise quantitative tightening (QT), potentially pressuring equity valuations and increasing long-term yields.

• Markets anticipate a shift towards a more 'loyal' central bank, though Warsh’s history suggests he may maintain some institutional independence.

• Global central banks, particularly the ECB and BoE, may have to recalibrate their easing cycles if the Fed pivots to a more hawkish stance under new leadership.
importance:
• The Fed Chair is the most influential figure in global finance, dictating the cost of capital for the world’s largest economy.

• Traders use the nomination to gauge the future path of the 'Trump Trade', particularly regarding dollar strength and inflation expectations.

• The sudden collapse in gold and silver prices highlights the sensitivity of 'safe-haven' assets to shifts in US monetary leadership.

title: Alphabet's Waymo seeks $16bn funding at $110bn valuation
content: Alphabet-owned Waymo is reportedly in talks to raise approximately $16 billion, with Alphabet itself contributing $13 billion to the round. The deal, reported on 31 January, would value the autonomous driving pioneer at nearly $110 billion despite an active safety investigation.
summary: Waymo targets a $110 billion valuation in a massive $16 billion funding round led by parent company Alphabet.
context:
• Waymo currently operates the only commercialised, fully driverless robotaxi service in several major US cities including San Francisco and Phoenix.

• Alphabet has been under pressure from investors to demonstrate a clear path to profitability for its 'Other Bets' segment.

• The funding news follows a period of intense competition in the autonomous vehicle (AV) sector from Tesla’s 'Cybercab' and various Chinese rivals.
happened:
• Reports on 31 January detailed a financing structure involving external investors such as Sequoia Capital, DST Global, and Dragoneer.

• The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) opened an investigation on 29 January following a Waymo collision in Santa Monica.

• Alphabet (GOOGL) shares remained resilient as investors focused on the high valuation and the scaling potential of the Waymo fleet.
implications:
• The massive capital injection suggests Alphabet is doubling down on AV technology as its primary growth driver outside of Search.

• A $110 billion valuation sets a high benchmark for the upcoming IPO or funding rounds of other autonomous tech firms.

• Regulatory outcomes from the NHTSA investigation could delay the commercial rollout to new markets despite the fresh capital.
importance:
• It represents one of the largest private funding rounds in the technology sector for 2026, signaling robust appetite for AI-adjacent infrastructure.

• The involvement of top-tier venture capital firms alongside Alphabet validates the long-term commercial viability of robotaxis.

• Investors view Waymo as the 'pure-play' benchmark for the future of transportation and urban mobility.

title: UK Prime Minister concludes China trade trip amid Trump criticism
content: Sir Keir Starmer completed a high-profile trade mission to China on 30 January, securing a deal to halve tariffs on Scotch whisky. The visit drew sharp criticism from US President Donald Trump, who warned that the UK's business ties with Beijing are 'very dangerous'.
summary: The UK secures market access wins in China, but faces growing geopolitical pressure from the US over its trade relationship with Beijing.
context:
• The UK government is pursuing a 'more sophisticated' relationship with China, balancing economic necessity with security concerns.

• China recently agreed to lift sanctions on several British politicians as a gesture of goodwill during the summit.

• The US administration has threatened 100% tariffs on allies that move too close to China, creating a dilemma for post-Brexit Britain.
happened:
• Tariffs on Scotch whisky were reduced from 10% to 5% on 30 January, providing a boost to the UK's high-end spirits exporters.

• The FTSE 100 closed 0.51% higher at 10,223.54 on 29 January as investors cheered the potential for increased market access.

• Sterling (GBP/USD) fell nearly 0.9% over the week to 1.37, partly due to the geopolitical friction between the UK and US.
implications:
• The UK may face 'secondary' trade barriers from the US if it continues to diverge from Washington’s decoupling strategy.

• Increased trade with China could provide a necessary growth cushion for the UK economy, which has lagged G7 peers.

• Multi-national corporations with dual UK-US-China exposure may need to restructure supply chains to avoid cross-border tariff traps.
importance:
• The story highlights the growing difficulty for mid-sized economies to maintain 'neutral' trade stances in a bipolar world.

• Currency traders are monitoring the 'Special Relationship' for signs of strain that could weigh on the Pound.

• It serves as a case study for how trade policy is being used as a tool of geopolitical leverage in 2026.
